content.description:
Starting from your boat, step onto a ledge and use a good side pull and an undercling to get established. Once the boat is NO LONGER UNDER YOU, climb up using side pulls for about a meter before switching to crimps. After passing a surprisingly useful pocket 2/3 of the way up, jugs lead to an easy top out.

Alternatively, start from in the water (bumping the grade up to V3) and mantle up onto the starting ledge.

Get back down by jumping into the lake, or walking through the woods 50m to the west where the boat can safely pick you up.



Located on the north side of the bay, this climb is located on the only vertical wall. The starting ledge, usually 2 feet above the water surface, is the obvious give away for where this climb starts. The volcanic nature of this rock makes the line clearly stand out.

Water

The beautiful rock surrounding this small bay, known for its three glacially formed potholes (with potentially more underwater), is most frequently used as a popular picnic destination or as a canoe portage route. It has several steep walls on its north side, with a few fun DWS routes on bullet Nipissing Diabase. 
  
 While the climbing in this bay is not within the bounds of the Whitefish River First Nation owned land, it does fall within an area of Special Consideration to the local community. It is imperative that visitors act responsibly and with respect, making sure to tread lightly on this area of cultural and historic significance.
